subject: RBNZ buys NZD 600mln of government bonds in QE operations as targetted
RBA adds AUD 1.52bln to banking system through repos vs. Prev. AUD 333mln
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Rio Tinto provides quarterly updates, Japanese government has decided on a Japanese cash handout of JPY 100k per citizen
content:
AUSTRALIA

Brambles (BXB AT) - Co. 9-month sales rev. rose 6% Y/Y, while it guides FY20 underlying profit to increase 3%-5%. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT) - Co. quarterly Pilbara iron ore shipments 72.9mln tons vs. Prev. 69.1mln tons Y/Y, iron ore production 77.8mln tons vs. Prev. 76.0mln tons Y/Y, while quarterly copper output fell 8% to 133k tons and it cuts FY20 capex guidance to USD 5.0bln-6.0bln from around USD 7.0bln. (Newswires)

Sandfire Resources (SFR AT) - Co. Q3 copper output 17.9k tons vs. Prev. 18.2k tons Q/Q, while it withdraws FY20 guidance. (Newswires)

Airlines - Virgin Australia (VAH AT) and Qantas (QAN AT) are to operate services on government-backed domestic networks in which the government will underwrite flights between capital and regional cities. (SMH)

 

JAPAN

FujiFilm (4901 JT) - Kaneka agrees to supply active pharmaceutical ingredients for Co.’s Avigan drug. (Newswires)

Itochu (8001 JT) - Article in Nikkei Asian Review suggested Co.’s large bet in China’s CITIC in which it took a 10% stake 5 years ago could be at risk of a writedown which would put Itochu at risk of missing fiscal 2019 net forecasts. ~(Newswires)

Japan Airlines (9201 JT) - Co. reports prelim. Q1 oper loss of JPY 20bln. (Newswires)

Matsumotokyoshi Holdings (3088 JT) - Co. March same store sales fell 10.6% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Nippon Paint (4612 JT) - Co. is said to have developed anti-coronavirus coating. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. is to extend suspension of production at all US plants until May. (Newswires)

Subaru (7270 JT) - Co. is to suspend output at its aircraft parts factory in Aichi. (Newswires)

Other News

Japanese government has decided on a cash handout of JPY 100k per citizen. (Nikkei) 

The government is expected to postpone the release of its monthly economic assessment report. (Newswires)

China’s Global Times tweeted that 98% of Japanese companies with facilities in southern China have resumed production and over 40% had returned to full production. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Seegen (096530 KS) - Co. partner CirrusDX Laboratory received emergency use authorization from US FDA for COVID-19 testing. (Newswires)

SK Telecom (017670 KS) - Co. esports JV received sponsorship from BMW. (Yonhap)

Other News - South Korea will reportedly announce economic policy package for employment next week. (Newswires)

US President Trump unveils a phased approach to re-opening the economy and says national shutdown is not a sustainable long-term plan
content:
Says

  • Some states can reopen sooner than others.
  • Expects the economy to boom once opened.
  • Re-opening will be in 3 phases and will be gradual.
  • Governors will be empowered to tailor approach to their own states and if they need to stay closed, that will be permitted.

New York Fed purchased USD 428mln in agency-CMBS vs. USD 1.8bln offered on Thursday
US Senate Democrat leader Schumer says talks on additional relief funding are ongoing

subject: US equity futures gap higher with Emini S&P up 2.7% in a continuation of the gains after details of the re-opening guidelines for the US economy and positive results from clinical trials of Gilead's Remdesivir for treatment on COVID-19 patients
IMF official says will analyze proposal by Argentina to restructure its debt
BoC Governor Poloz says when we get back to normal, interest rates will certainly increase and that it will take the economy a couple of years to make up for lost ground
CME raises crude oil NYMEX margins by 11.9% to USD 7500/contract from USD 6700/contract for May
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US President Trump told Governors they call the shots regarding reopening the economy and that some could begin before May 1st if they want to, while he will conduct a press conference on re-opening the economy at 1800EDT/ 2300BST where he will explain guidelines for opening up and an official noted that guidelines will be flexible and on data driven recommendations. Furthermore, phase one of the guidelines recommends closed schools should remain shut, that people maximize distance when in public and that gatherings over 10 people should generally be avoided, while bars should remain closed but large venues such as restaurants, theatres and sporting venues could open with strict physical distancing. (Newswires)

Reports noted that Chicago hospital treating severe COVID-19 patients with Gilead (GILD) antiviral medicine Remdesivir is seeing rapid recoveries in fever and respiratory symptoms, with nearly all in the closely observed clinical trial discharged in a week. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that Democrats are blocking funding for the PPP and calls on them to support refilling funds for the programme which ran out of funds earlier today, although there were later comments from US Senate Majority Leader McConnell that there has been "absolutely no progress" among lawmakers to come to an agreement on paycheck funding for small businesses. (Newswires)

NY Governor Cuomo said the stay-at-home and business closure orders will be extended by two weeks to 15th May. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said the emergency business loan programme is to be extended and will not be lifting border restrictions with the US for "a significant amount of time". (Newswires)

UK Foreign Secretary Raab said the current UK measures must remain in place for at least the next 3 weeks and suggested it would not be responsible to pre-judge what experts will say in three weeks’ time. (Newswires

 

ASIA-PAC

PBoC said that it will maintain the normalisation of monetary policy for as long as possible and will keep room for monetary policy adjustments. Furthermore, other reports noted the PBoC will continue to guide credit funds to support smaller firms through RRR targeted cuts, re-lending and other measures, while it is also said to explore a new framework for injecting reserve money and managing liquidity. (Newswires)

Japanese government has decided on a Japanese cash handout of JPY 100k per citizen. (Nikkei)  

 

UK/EU

BoE's Tenreyro said MPC is co-ordinating closely with other policymakers in the Bank and in government, while she added the BoE will do whatever it can to minimise the economic disruption that the crisis could cause for households, businesses and financial markets. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson spokesperson said we will not ask for an extension to the Brexit transition period and if the EU asks for such, we will say no. (Newswires)

ECB President Lagarde said the ECB is fully prepared to increase the size of its asset purchase programmes and adjust their composition, by as much as necessary and for as long as needed, while it will explore all options and all contingencies to support the economy. (Newswires)

ECB provided temporarily relief regarding capital requirements for market risk, in which it temporarily allows lower capital requirements and aims to maintain market making activities, as well as liquidity and will review the decision in 6 months. (Newswires)

French President Macron said EU countries have no choice but to set up a fund that could issue common debt with a common guarantee, while he added the fund would allow member states to finance according to their needs rather than size of economies. (FT)

Swiss Government has announced a gradual relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions from April 27th. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

Russian Energy Minister Novak and Saudi Energy Minister held a call and expressed commitment to the oil cut deals; willing to take more measures with other OPEC+ members and oil producers if needed. (Newswires)

OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report stated 2020 global oil demand growth forecast was slashed by 6.9mln BPD Y/Y, while Q2 contraction is expected to be around 12mln BPD with April seeing the largest contraction of around 20mln BPD. (Newswires) 

 

US

Fed's Harker (voter, hawk) said the Fed is not going to bring all financial markets to where they were but it can help them function and that policy will stay low until the dual mandate can be reached. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (voter, dove) said the US economy will start to grow in Q3 and believes peak unemployment will be at the mid-high teens but expects it to fall to 8-10% by year end. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (non-voter, dove) said hopefully the rebound in the economy means the Fed's lending will be repaid quickly and the balance sheet will "resolve itself", while he is looking for further market stresses and stated the Fed is willing to do more with Treasury backed facilities if needed. (Newswires)

  • US Initial Jobless Claims w/e 5245k vs. Exp. 5105.0k (Prev. 6606.0k, Rev. 6615k)
  • US Building Permits: Number (Mar) 1.353M vs. Exp. 1.3M (Prev. 1.452M)
  • US Housing Starts Number (Mar) 1.216M vs. Exp. 1.3M (Prev. 1.599M, Rev. 1.564M)

 

MARKET RECAP

The stock market was choppy on Thursday, but ultimately firmer and continues to be unreactive to dire economic data points. Futures before the US cash open had indicated strength, although downside was felt shortly after the open, particularly in value-oriented sectors such as Industrials, Energy and Financials (MS, like other large US banks, missed estimates as it grew its credit provisions) leading the losses, and remaining the underperformers as indices retraced ground in the latter part of the session; note, heavy losses in Boeing (BA) saw the DJIA underperform the SPX, while strong gains in momentum/growth names (primarily located in the tech/telecoms sector) saw the NDQ outperform, particularly as Amazon’s (AMZN) COVID-induced rally continued. Morgan Stanley (MS) earnings missed expectations although its sales and trading revenues were solid, particularly FICC which came in at 2.2bln, much firmer than expectations. Blackrock (BLK) beat on EPS and revenue although AUM missed, BLK also raised its dividend. Bank of New York Mellon (BK) saw solid EPS & revenue beats while it only had 169mln in credit provisions. Elsewhere, Abbott ABT) beat on EPS, revenue was in-line, it suspended FY guidance but say Worldwide Medical Device sales grew 1.4% and FreeStyle Libre worldwide sales +49.3%. Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) saw a solid report. SPX +0.59% at 2800, NDX +1.93% at 8758, DJIA +0.14% at 23538.

The Treasury bid continued as equities slumped lower in recent ranges, with the shape of the curve bull-flattening; the Treasury Bond June future move over one-and-a-half points upwards, while the 2-year futures were little changed. By settlement, 2s unchanged at 0.20%, 10s -3.5bps at 0.60%, and 30s -7bps at 1.20%. Similar to Wednesday, the lions’ share of strength came in the European session before the upward trajectory levelled-off in later trade, with real money accounts reportedly still heavy sellers into the Fed’s buyback operations. Further, as yields hit two-week lows, investors were likely cautious about extending the move. For instance, 2-year yield secular low was 0.143% on 9/20/2011, today’s low print of 0.187% is the lowest of this recent rally, a mere 4bps, or 2+/32, off the lows. More broadly, some Bond market participants have likely been enticed into longs given recent dismal data points, while value proxies in the equity market lead losses. In credit, Lipper data showed USD 5.184bln of inflows into investment grade rated funds in the latest week, the first inflow in six weeks, while HY rated funds saw their third week of inflows, a sign of stabilisation in the market, no doubt the Fed’s latest Primary/Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facilities will be reinvigorating investors as the bank has shown its commitment to backstopping credit markets. It is worth noting also that FRA-OIS spreads widened slightly amid USD LIBOR rose after eight consecutive declines; white strip Eurodollars were offered. US T-note futures (M0) settled 2+ ticks higher at 139-07+.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - April 16th: Stocks eke out gains and look through chunky unemployment
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

April 16th: Stocks eke out gains and look through chunky unemployment

·        SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude flat/up.

·        REARVIEW: 5.254mln Jobless Claims, Philly Fed lowest since 1980; PPP runs out of funding with Congress at odds; MS misses estimates as credit provisions build.

·        COMING UP: Data: Chinese GDP, Industrial Output & Retail Sales, EZ CPI (Final).

MARKET WRAP

The stock market was choppy on Thursday, but ultimately firmer and continues to be unreactive to dire economic data points. Futures before the US cash open had indicated strength, although downside was felt shortly after the open, particularly in value-oriented sectors such as Industrials, Energy and Financials (MS, like other large US banks, missed estimates as it grew its credit provisions) leading the losses, and remaining the underperformers as indices retraced ground in the latter part of the session; note, heavy losses in Boeing (BA) saw the DJIA underperform the SPX, while strong gains in momentum/growth names (primarily located in the tech/telecoms sector) saw the NDQ outperform, particularly as Amazon’s (AMZN) COVID-induced rally continued. Meanwhile, The TPLEX’s bull-flattening continued, with debate growing on whether stocks and bonds have resumed their pre-COVID correlation, or if the bond market knows something the equity market doesn’t. The Dollar strengthened as activity currencies gave back recent strength. Meanwhile, crude futures gyrated to the rhythm of equity appetite, although found some additional strength on some Saudi and Russia jawboning just prior to the US cash equity close.

VIRUS CASE COUNT

Figures provided as of Thursday (via state official health departments) against Wednesday:

·        US cases rise 4.5% to 632,548 (prev. +4.6% at 605,390), death toll rises 9.9% to 27,012 (prev. +10.5% at 24,582).

·        NEW YORK death toll rises 5% to 12,192 (prev. +6.9% at 11,586).

·        SPAIN cases rise to 182,816 (prev. 177,633), death toll rises to 19,130 (prev. 18,579).

·        ITALY cases +2.3% to 168,941 (Prev. +1.6% at 165,155); death toll 2.4% to 22,170 (prev. +2.7% at 21,645).

·        GERMANY cases rise to 130,450 (+2,866) deaths stand at 3,569 (+315).

·        FRANCE cases rise +2.5% to 108,847 (prev. +5.5% to 106,206), death toll rises 4.4% to 17,920 (prev. +9.1% at 17,167).

·        UK cases rise to 103,093 (prev. 98,476), death toll rises 6.69% to 13,729 (prev. +6.29% at 12,868).

·        CANADA cases rise to 28,899 (prev. 27,540), death toll rises to 1,048 (prev. 954).

·        SWITZERLAND cases rise to 26,732 (prev. 26,336), death toll rises to 1,017 (prev. 973).

NORTH AMERICA

GEOPOLITICS: Eleven Iranian Revolutionary Guard boats made dangerous and harassing actions against six US naval ships in international waters in the North Arabian Gulf, while US crews took action deemed appropriate to avoid a collision. Elsewhere, Chinese Foreign Ministry says that the US’ false accusations regarding nuclear testing are not worth refuting.

STIMULUS: The SBA said it is currently unable to enrol a new Paycheck Protection Program at this time. The USD 350bln of PPP had been depleted earlier on in the session, as was widely touted at in recent sessions. The Democrats and Republicans are still negotiating, and some had hoped they would come to an agreement on Friday. However, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated both sides are still far apart, and to deepen the woes, Senate Majority Leader McConnell said there has been “absolutely no progress” among lawmakers to come to an agreement. Top House GOP McCarthy said today that he sees no reason to offer a “fig leaf” to the Democrats on the small business funding bill. Trump tweeted that the Democrats are blocking funding for the PPP and calls on them to support refilling funds. Note, some banks, such as Wells Fargo, stated they would continue to prepare for SBA loans.

LOCKDOWN: President Trump said the aggressive strategy is working and data suggests the nation has passed the peak on new coronavirus cases. Furthermore, President Trump added he will be announcing new guidelines on reopening the economy on Thursday at 1800 ET / 23:00 GMT.

TRUMP SENATE NOMINEES: Trump urged the Senate to confirm his nominees to vacancies across the administration or formally adjourn and threatened to use executive powers to try and force both chambers of Congress to adjourn, while Senate Majority Leader McConnell later spoke with President Trump and pledged to find ways to confirm Trump nominees critical to fighting coronavirus although noted it will require consent from the Democratic leader.

CENTRAL BANKS

FED: The NY Fed will begin a regular publication of its Weekly Economic Index (WEI) from Thursday, which will provide timely information on the state of the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic.

PBOC said that it will maintain the normalisation of monetary policy for as long as possible and will keep room for monetary policy adjustments. The bank will also continue to guide credit funds to support smaller firms through RRR targeted cuts, re-lending and other measures.

ECB provided a temporarily relief for capital requirements for market risk, which temporarily allows lower capital requirements with the aim of maintaining market making activities and liquidities; the ECB will review the decision in six months.

ECB PRESIDENT LAGARDE said the bank is fully prepared to increase the size of its asset purchase programmes and adjust their composition, by as much as necessary and for as long as needed. It will explore all options and all contingencies to support the economy. Assessing further requests for Euro swap lines. ECB’s Schnabel said that a rate cut would not have helped at a time (March 12th) when profits at banks were already under pressure.

RBNZ GOVERNOR ORR said negative interest rates have not been ruled out, while he added that they are at the end of the beginning regarding monetary stimulus and suggested negative rates remain on the table as well as direct financing.

EUROPE

STIMULUS: French President Macron said EU countries have no choice but to set up a fund that could issue common debt with a common guarantee, the FT reported. Macron added that the fund would allow member states to finance according to their needs, rather than size of their economies. Italy will “never” activate the ESM bailout fund but might agree to use it if the EU summit (April 23rd) decides to remove conditions on its use, according to the Industry Minister cited by ANSA. Meanwhile, Italy reportedly expects its 2020 budget deficit at 9-10% of GDP, according to a government source, who added the forecast includes the deficit impact of the stimulus package set to be approved this month. Later in the session, Eurogroup Chief Centeno said Europe needs to be more imaginative to tackle the virus, and is mulling EU-wide taxation.

UK has extended its lockdown measures for another three weeks, as was expected following the government’s COBRA meeting today. Foreign Secretary Raab said it would not be responsible to pre-judge what experts will say in three weeks’ time.

DATA

WEEKLY INITIAL JOBLESS CLAIMS printed 5.245mln in the week ending April 11th; analysts had expected 5.105mln (range:1.4-8.0mln), from a revised 6.61mln. Oxford Economics said the data now appears to have reached a “vertiginous plateau.” The consultancy now anticipates the official nonfarm payrolls data for April will show a loss of 24 million jobs and the unemployment rate spiking to 14%, while the participation rate will fall beneath 60%. “While some jobs will be recouped as activity rebounds, we don’t expect the economy to reach the February 2020 level of employment until early 2022.” And for the jobless claims themselves, Oxford Economics says that while it now appears that we have passed the peak in layoffs, “jobless claims are poised to remain extraordinarily high in coming weeks as the economy plunges deeper into a recession.” NOTE: Next’s week’s initial jobless claims will coincide with the survey period for the BLS’ Employment Situation Report.

PHILLY FED: The headline collapsed to -56.6 in April, a larger fall than the -30.0 expected, from the prior -12.7, and the lowest print since 1980. The forward-looking 6-month expectations index, however, was up just shy of eight points to 43.0, although new orders plunged to -70.9 from -15.5. The details chime with the grim Empire Manufacturing report out on Wednesday. “Manufacturing is in the midst of a broad-based and significant retrenchment,” Oxford Economics said, “the silver lining is that manufacturers believe the downturn will be short-lived, but the recovery is likely going to be very gradual given the severity of the recession.” OxEco adds that manufacturing is facing “gale-force headwinds in the form of sharply weaker demand, supply chain disruptions, tight financial conditions and historic levels of uncertainty,” and that even once activity begins to eventually rebound, “the recovery is likely to be slow and risks being uneven across various manufacturing sectors.”

CRUDE

WTI (K0) SETTLED UNCHANGED AT USD 19.87/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLED USD 0.13 HIGHER AT USD 27.82/BBL

Crude markets furloughed earlier strength to settle subdued on Thursday. The benchmarks had made gains in European trade alongside risk appetite/equity futures. However, as the US session got underway, momentum was lost, and prices found their way into negative territory. Specific to energy markets, news flow has been light. On Wednesday evening it was reported that Texas oil regulators would meet on April 21st to further discuss potential production limits after the meeting on Tuesday failed to yield results. Meanwhile, ConocoPhillips (COP) announced it is production by approximately 100k BPD to a gross 35k BOD; added that it is cutting production across Canada and the US until market conditions improve. Elsewhere, Russia’s St. Petersburg’s oil terminal said the country has almost run out of spare storage space in Western regions.

OPEC MONTHLY OIL MARKET REPORT slashed its 2020 global oil demand growth forecast by 6.9mln BPD from the prior report. Q2 contraction is expected to be around 12mln BPD, with April seeing the largest contraction of around 20mln BPD (note IEA said April could be as low as -29mln BPD). OPEC sees 2020 global oil demand in Q3 contracting about 6mln BPD and around 3.5mln BPD in Q4. The market surplus was expected to reach around 15mln BPD in Q2 2020. Preliminary data indicates that global oil supply in March increased by 620k BPD to average of 99.86mln BPD, up 910k BPD Y/Y.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 2+ TICKS HIGHER AT 139-07+.

The Treasury bid continued as equities slumped lower in recent ranges, with the shape of the curve bull-flattening; the Treasury Bond June future move over one-and-a-half points upwards, while the 2-year futures were little changed. By settlement, 2s unchanged at 0.20%, 10s -3.5bps at 0.60%, and 30s -7bps at 1.20%. Similar to Wednesday, the lions’ share of strength came in the European session before the upward trajectory levelled-off in later trade, with real money accounts reportedly still heavy sellers into the Fed’s buyback operations. Further, as yields hit two-week lows, investors were likely cautious about extending the move. For instance, 2-year yield secular low was 0.143% on 9/20/2011, today’s low print of 0.187% is the lowest of this recent rally, a mere 4bps, or 2+/32, off the lows. More broadly, some Bond market participants have likely been enticed into longs given recent dismal data points, while value proxies in the equity market lead losses. In credit, Lipper data showed USD 5.184bln of inflows into investment grade rated funds in the latest week, the first inflow in six weeks, while HY rated funds saw their third week of inflows, a sign of stabilisation in the market, no doubt the Fed’s latest Primary/Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facilities will be reinvigorating investors as the bank has shown its commitment to backstopping credit markets. It is worth noting also that FRA-OIS spreads widened slightly amid USD LIBOR rose after eight consecutive declines; white strip Eurodollars were offered.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.59% at 2800, NDX +1.93% at 8758, DJIA +0.14% at 23538.

SECTORS: Energy -3.97%, Financials -1.74%, Industrials -0.84%, Real Estate -0.6%, Materials -0.53%, Utilities +0.07%, Communication Svs +0.43%, Cons Stpl +0.8%, Technology +1.24%, Cons Disc +1.94%, Health +2.2%.

EARNINGS: Morgan Stanley (MS) earnings missed expectations although its sales and trading revenues were solid, particularly FICC which came in at 2.2bln, much firmer than expectations. Blackrock (BLK) beat on EPS and revenue although AUM missed, BLK also raised its dividend. Bank of New York Mellon (BK) saw solid EPS & revenue beats while it only had 169mln in credit provisions. Elsewhere, Abbott ABT) beat on EPS, revenue was in-line, it suspended FY guidance but say Worldwide Medical Device sales grew 1.4% and FreeStyle Libre worldwide sales +49.3%. Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) saw a solid report.

STOCK NEWS: Apple (AAPL) is to boost its wearables business by launching over-ear headphones. Costco (COST) raised its quarterly dividend to USD 0.70/shr. Gilead Sciences (GILD) is reportedly in talks to purchase a significant stake in Arcus Biosciences (RCUS). Baxter International (BAX) is seeing a surge of demand for its good. Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) is reportedly retooling its website to sell fewer items as it deals with a surge of order volumes, according to WSJ citing sources – the stock lead gains in the Discretionary sector. Starboard withdrew their director candidates to eBay’s (EBAY) board. Ford (F) China sales -34.9% Y/Y, although it gained 2.2% market share. Netflix (NFLX) continued its rise benefiting from a PT upgrade at Goldman Sachs to a tied street-high of USD 490/shr and expects it to report earnings better than estimates next week.

FOREX

USD: The grind in the buck followed on from yesterday and is now back above 100. Yesterday, the rise was largely a part of sour risk sentiment, although today sentiment was mixed. Equities flirted between positive and negative territory with the three major indices mixed. The coronavirus impact is clearly showing in data now, there were 5mln initial jobless claims, a slower pace from last two weeks, while Philly Fed saw a grim release, particularly forward-looking new orders which printed -70.9 from a prior -15.5.

EUR: EURUSD continues to sell off amid broad dollar strength while comments from ECB President Lagarde noted the bank is fully prepared to increase the size of its asset purchase programme as much as necessary and for as long as needed, adding they will explore all options to support the economy while the bank is assessing requests for Euro swap lines.

GBP: As expected, the UK government extended the lockdown by three more weeks (May 7th, from today). GBP was also a victim of the greenback which saw cable back beneath 1.25 to find support just above 1.24. Analysts at Lloyd’s suggest a breakthrough 1.2440 “will suggest we have made a lower high within a developing range earlier than expected, with 1.2175-1.2050 the main support/target.” New Jersey COVID cases +6% to 75317 (prev. +3% to 71,030).

AUD: The Aussie is weaker today amid risk sentiment, given the cyclical nature of the currency. Overnight, some support was provided after its unemployment rate ticked up less than expected to 5.2% (exp. 5.7%), while employment rose by 5.9k, a large beat on the expected -40k. However, RBC highlight that the survey period took place in the beginning of March and therefore does not take into account the whole COVID-19 impact.

NZD: Weaker today amid risk appetite, but particularly weaker than its antipodean counterpart after dovish commentary from RBNZ Governor Orr who noted the bank is not ruling out negative rates. The comment saw NZD trade beneath 0.60 throughout the session to lows of 0.5923.

CAD: Out of the cyclicals saw relative outperformance and trades only marginally weaker against the buck with little seen in reaction to Feb. manufacturing sales. Canadian bank Scotia writes “CAD remains a slave to markets flows as trading conditions remain thin and somewhat illiquid it appears”.

However, some of the price action could be impacted by PM Abe, who declared a nationwide national emergency. The government, however, has decided on a cash handout of JPY 100k per citizen, according to reports.

MXN: The peso was the clear underperformer in the EMFX space after Mexico was downgraded from Fitch to BBB-; Outlook Stable (prev. BBB; outlook negative) and says economic shock from coronavirus will result to a severe recession in Mexico. JP Morgan state that this downgrade shows “Mexico is seemingly on a path of deterioration of business confidence and regulatory institutional framework that could hamper the macroeconomic outlook in the longer run”.

RUB: The Ruble was firmer today despite a rising dollar and continued weakness in crude prices (although to a lesser extent than recent days). Meanwhile, the Finance Ministry said it will inject USD 26bln into the economy from the national wealth fund if oil prices remain where they are now, while its planned measures to fight the coronavirus crisis will cost 2.8% of GDP.

analysis_details: The Treasury bid continued as equities slumped lower in recent ranges, with the shape of the curve bull-flattening; the Treasury Bond June future move over one-and-a-half points upwards, while the 2-year futures were little changed. By settlement, 2s unchanged at 0.20%, 10s -3.5bps at 0.60%, and 30s -7bps at 1.20%. Similar to Wednesday, the lions’ share of strength came in the European session before the upward trajectory levelled-off in later trade, with real money accounts reportedly still heavy sellers into the Fed’s buyback operations. Further, as yields hit two-week lows, investors were likely cautious about extending the move. For instance, 2-year yield secular low was 0.143% on 9/20/2011, today’s low print of 0.187% is the lowest of this recent rally, a mere 4bps, or 2+/32, off the lows. More broadly, some Bond market participants have likely been enticed into longs given recent dismal data points, while value proxies in the equity market lead losses. In credit, Lipper data showed USD 5.184bln of inflows into investment grade rated funds in the latest week, the first inflow in six weeks, while HY rated funds saw their third week of inflows, a sign of stabilisation in the market, no doubt the Fed’s latest Primary/Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facilities will be reinvigorating investors as the bank has shown its commitment to backstopping credit markets. It is worth noting also that FRA-OIS spreads widened slightly amid USD LIBOR rose after eight consecutive declines; white strip Eurodollars were offered.

analysis_details:
• Crude markets furloughed earlier strength to settle subdued on Thursday. The benchmarks had made gains in European trade alongside risk appetite/equity futures. However, as the US session got underway, momentum was lost, and prices found their way into negative territory. Specific to energy markets, news flow has been light. On Wednesday evening it was reported that Texas oil regulators would meet on April 21st to further discuss potential production limits after the meeting on Tuesday failed to yield results. Meanwhile, ConocoPhillips (COP) announced it is production by approximately 100k BPD to a gross 35k BOD; added that it is cutting production across Canada and the US until market conditions improve. Elsewhere, Russia's St. Petersburg's oil terminal said the country has almost run out of spare storage space in Western regions.
  • OPEC MONTHLY OIL MARKET REPORT slashed its 2020 global oil demand growth forecast by 6.9mln BPD from the prior report. Q2 contraction is expected to be around 12mln BPD, with April seeing the largest contraction of around 20mln BPD (note IEA said April could be as low as -29mln BPD). OPEC sees 2020 global oil demand in Q3 contracting about 6mln BPD and around 3.5mln BPD in Q4. The market surplus was expected to reach around 15mln BPD in Q2 2020. Preliminary data indicates that global oil supply in March increased by 620k BPD to average of 99.86mln BPD, up 910k BPD Y/Y.

Daily FX Wrap: almost 100 and out for the DXY, as the Dollar continues its recovery rally
content:
USD

More dire US data in the form of jobless claims (topped consensus, but below last week’s record high and the upper end of estimate range) and another worrying regional Fed survey (Philly findings just as bleak if not more concerning than NY manufacturing yesterday) only stalled the Buck’s latest recovery rally for a while. Indeed, the Greenback remains firm and on track to net gains vs its major counterparts, bar a very select few, with the index trying to establish a foothold back above 100.000 between 100.190-99.585 parameters.

NZD/AUD/CAD

The Kiwi has been flagging ever since RBNZ Governor Orr reaffirmed dovish policy guidance overnight via NIRP, more QE and even direct financing, with Nzd/Usd unable to revisit 0.6000 even during bouts of relative risk-on trade. Conversely, its Aussie neighbour has managed to reclaim 0.6300+ status as the Aud/Nzd cross inches towards 1.0600 in wake of pre-full coronavirus lockdown jobs data that beat forecasts on payroll and unemployment rate counts. Meanwhile, the Loonie has been choppy tracking crude undulations, but mostly off post-BoC lows within a 1.4136-1.4062 range and with some fleeting support from Canadian manufacturing sales exceeding expectations before acknowledging the downward revision that almost offset the margin of upside and of course mindful of the fact that March will see significant payback if Wednesday’s -9% monthly GDP projection by the stats office proves accurate.

EUR/GBP/CHF/JPY 

Also enduring volatile Thursday sessions, albeit largely underperforming against the Dollar with the Euro never really comfortable on the 1.0900 handle, but propped by decent option expiries layered down to 1.0840 into the NY cut before breaking lower and also gleaning some impetus from the usual 4 pm London fix buying vs the Pound that kept the cross above 0.8700 to the detriment of Cable. In fact, Sterling had already relinquished 1.2500 and is now sub-1.2450 following dovish/downbeat commentary from BoE’s Tenreyro on balance and awaiting news on an anticipated extension to UK measures to combat the COVID-19 spread. Elsewhere, fluctuations in risk sentiment fed through to the safe-haven Franc and Yen, but left them both strong vs the single currency and broader cross terms.

SCANDI/EM

The Crowns have overcome several wobbles to emerge on the front foot against the Euro, if not the Buck, irrespective of choppy oil prices and benign Swedish inflation forecasts or squabbles over Riksbank policy, but EMs have been more sensitive to specifics and independent factors, like Fitch downgrading Mexico to put the Peso under pressure and looming Chinese data keeping the Yuan in check after firmer PBoC Usd/Cny midpoint fix and rhetoric signalling more policy easing, including further targeted RRR cuts.

US EQUITY OPEN: US equities reverse some of prior day losses
content:
MACRO: Asia was mixed overnight, though European bourses are higher, led by tech after TSM's numbers buoyed the sector. The positive trend has followed through to the US with three major indices marginally higher. The dollar has retained its bid, gold is slightly above neutral. The Treasury curve is little changed, but the bias is towards a slightly steeper curve (overnight, 2-year yields fell below 20bps). Crude benchmarks are recovering slightly after the recent steep falls.

SECTORS: Sectors are mixed, energy and financials are lagging once again with the latter being weighed on by MS after an EPS and revenue miss. Health Care leading the pack buoyed by gains in ABT after its earnings, also an update from Baxter (BAX) who have seen a surge in demand for its medical devices. Technology also firmer with gains in semiconductors after solid TSM figures.

EARNINGS: Morgan Stanley (MS) earnings missed expectations although its sales and trading revenues were solid, particularly FICC which came in at 2.2bln much firmer than expectations. Blackrock (BLK) beat on EPS and revenue although AUM missed, BLK also raised dividend. Bank of New York Mellon (BK) saw solid EPS & revenue beats while it only had 169mln in credit provisions. Elsewhere, Abbott ABT) beat on EPS, revenue was in-line. It suspended FY guidance but say Worldwide Medical Device sales +1.4% and FreeStyle Libre worldwide sales +49.3%. Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) saw a solid report.

STOCK NEWS: Apple (AAPL) is to boost its wearables business by launching over-ear headphones. Costco (COST) raised its quarterly dividend to USD 0.70/shr. Gilead Sciences (GILD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) is reportedly in talks to purchase a significant stake in Arcus Biosciences (RCUS). Baxter International (BAX) is seeing a surge of demand for its good. Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) is reportedly retooling its website to sell fewer items as it deals with a surge of order volumes, according to WSJ citing sources. Starboard withdrew their director candidates to eBay’s (EBAY) board. Ford (F) China sales -34.9% Y/Y, although it gained 2.2% market share. CRUDE: There is talk this morning that US producers are facing little other option than to cut production given the recent demand hit and hefty inventory builds, along with yesterday's report that the US might pay producers to keep crude in the ground. From an equity trader's perspective, the weakness in crude after such a significant supply cut deal highlights just how dire the lack of demand is, and provides reasons for equity traders to remain cautious. 

CORONAVIRUS: President Trump stated that the US may have passed the peak of new cases, and will deliver remarks today talking about reopening the economy. However, for equities, the virus may not be the main focus. JPM notes the trend of virus data has been constructive for about two weeks now, and it now seems that equity traders are paying attention to data (grim) and corporate earnings (weaker), and it is "an active concern", which JPM says may signal that the stock market rally seen April may be a bit "long in the tooth". Back to the virus data, as we have noted recently, desks are now looking for evidence that cases and death tolls are sustainably moving lower (they have certainly given that impression thus far), there is progress on vaccine development (timeframe is of course more medium/long-term on this), there is progress re-opening economies and re-starting economic activity, there is little 'second wave' of infections as economies re-open, and additionally, what 'shape' the recovery takes (v-shape is being increasingly questioned by some officials).

EARNINGS: Morgan Stanley (MS) earnings missed expectations although its sales and trading revenues were solid, particularly FICC which came in at 2.2bln much firmer than expectations. Blackrock (BLK) beat on EPS and revenue although AUM missed, BLK also raised dividend. Bank of New York Mellon (BK) saw solid EPS & revenue beats while it only had 169mln in credit provisions. Elsewhere, Abbott ABT) beat on EPS, revenue was in-line. It suspended FY guidance but say Worldwide Medical Device sales +1.4% and FreeStyle Libre worldwide sales +49.3%. Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) saw a solid report.

STOCK NEWS: Apple (AAPL) is to boost its wearables business by launching over-ear headphones. Costco (COST) raised its quarterly dividend to USD 0.70/shr. Gilead Sciences (GILD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) is reportedly in talks to purchase a significant stake in Arcus Biosciences (RCUS). Baxter International (BAX) is seeing a surge of demand for its good. Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) is reportedly retooling its website to sell fewer items as it deals with a surge of order volumes, according to WSJ citing sources. Starboard withdrew their director candidates to eBay’s (EBAY) board. Ford (F) China sales -34.9% Y/Y, although it gained 2.2% market share. 

MACRO VS. CTA: Nomura's quant desk notes that after yesterday's weak US data (retail and Empire Fed), most global macro hedge funds still favoured a cautious approach, premised on there being a double-dip in global equities. However, most CTAs (a proxy for algo traders) remain buyers. "CTAs specifically are coming up on a point at which the pace of their buying of US equity futures looks likely to slacken, and with global macro hedge funds seemingly trying to pull the market down with their selling, the balance between the two opposing forces looks likely to break down," Nomura says, adding "We think one key issue is where the NASDAQ 100 stands as of 22 April or so, specifically whether it manages to stay above the line at around 8,100 that we estimate represents the average entry point for CTAs’ buying of futures since the beginning of April." Its quants think that even if macro funds were to step up their selling of equities with the aim of capturing the second half of the double-dip they seem to be expecting, CTAs may simply pause and then go back to building longs, provided that the NASDAQ 100 does not drop below 8,100.

subject: Refile - Major FX expiry options for today's NY close
ANALYSIS: grim Philly Fed chimes with the message in Wednesday's Empire Fed survey; US manufacturing is in bad shape
analysis_details:
• The headline Philly Fed collapsed to -56.6 in April, a larger fall than the -30.0 expected, from the prior -12.7, and the lowest print since 1980. The forward looking 6-month expectations index, however, was up just shy of eight points to 43.0, although new orders plunged to -70.9 from -15.5.
  • The details chime with the grim Empire Manufacturing report out on Wednesday. "Manufacturing is in the midst of a broad-based and significant retrenchment," Oxford Economics said, "the silver lining is that manufacturers believe the downturn will be short-lived, but the recovery is likely going to be very gradual given the severity of the recession."
  • OxEco adds that manufacturing is facing "gale-force headwinds in the form of sharply weaker demand, supply chain disruptions, tight financial conditions and historic levels of uncertainty," and that even once activity begins to eventually rebound, "the recovery is likely to be slow and risks being uneven across various manufacturing sectors."

subject: Federal Reserve says its Paycheck Protection Programme Liquidity Facility is now fully operational, allowing credit to flow to financial intermediaries to make loans under the USD 350bln PPP
OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report (Apr): 2020 global oil demand growth forecast slashed by 6.9mln BPD
content:
MAIN POINTS

  • 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down by 6.9mln BPD from prior report. Q2 contraction is expected to be around 12mln BPD, with April seeing the largest contraction of around 20mln BPD.
  • 2020 global oil demand in Q3 is expected to contract about 6mln BPD and around 3.5mln BPD in Q4.
  • The market surplus was expected to reach around 15mln BPD in Q2 2020.
  • Preliminary data indicates that global oil supply in March increased by 620k BPD to average of 99.86mln BPD, up 910k BPD YY.

CORONAVIRUS

  • The world economy is forecast to face a severe recession this year, declining by 1.5%.
  • The underlying key assumption for the 2020 GDP growth forecast is that the impact of COVID-19-related developments outside China will continue well into 2Q20.
  • Crude and product trade flows have been notably affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and the uncertain outlook going forward, although there has been some lag in how the various regions have been affected.

OPEC

  • Following the recent OPEC+ meeting, demand for OPEC crude in 2020 is expected at 24.5mln BPD, around 5.4mln BPD lower than the 2019 level – this remains heavily contingent on market conditions
  • The share of OPEC crude oil in total global production increased by 0.6 ppt to 28.7% in March compared with the previous month.
  • In March, OPEC crude production rose by 821k BPD MM to average 28.61mln BPD, according to secondary sources. Crude output increased in mainly in Saudi Arabia, UAE and Kuwait, whilst production fell mostly in Venezuela, Iran and Libya.

NON-OPEC

  • Following the recent energy meetings, 2020 Former Soviet Union oil supply forecast revised down significantly by 1.65mln BPD.
  • Russia’s production is forecast to fall by 1.3mlnBPD to average 10.14mln BPD.

US

  • US crude oil production in 2020 is forecast to decline by 190kBPD YY to average 12.03mln BPD.
  • Preliminary data indicates that US crude oil imports continued to fall since the start of the year, averaging 6.3mln BPD in March, -7% YY.

OECD

  • OECD oil demand was revised down by 3.7mln BPD from the prior report.
  • Considering the latest developments, downward risks remain significant.
analysis_details:
• The revision downward to 2020 global oil demand by OPEC is not surprising, the forecast sits in the middle of the EIA STEO and IEA MOMR forecasts which saw their respective outlooks cuts by 5.6mln BPD and 9.3mln BPD respectively
  • The rise in OPEC supply was also alluded to prior to the report, albeit the report does not encapsulate Saudi’s significant production ramp-up
  • Note: The energy pact agreed on the weekend will be implemented from May 1st. Thus OPEC’s June report will capture these changes

subject: Fixed and FX latest: bonds and Buck dip post-US data
content: Another massive weekly US jobless claims number, but no new record and well under the top end of the forecast range. Hence, debt has drifted back from pre-release levels and the Dollar dipped before paring marginal losses to stand relatively unchanged. However, the April Philly Fed survey follows hot on the heels of Wednesday’s woeful NY manufacturing update and is arguably even bleaker as the employment index slumped into negative territory and new orders fell much further below zero. Next up, the OPEC monthly report could scupper the latest rebound in oil and derail the broader upturn in risk appetite ahead of the Wall Street open.

subject: ANALYSIS: Weekly jobless claims might imply April's NFP will be -24mln with the jobless rate spiking to 14%, according to Oxford Economics
analysis_details:
• Weekly initial jobless claims printed 5.245mln in the week ending 11th April; analysts had expected 5.105mln (range:1.4-8.0mln), from a revised 6.61mln. 
  • Oxford Economics says the data now appears to have reached a "vertiginous plateau." The consultancy now anticipates the official nonfarm payrolls data for April will show a loss of 24 million jobs and the unemployment rate spiking to 14%, while the participation rate will fall beneath 60%. "While some jobs will be recouped as activity rebounds, we don’t expect the economy to reach the February 2020 level of employment until early 2022." 
  • And for the jobless claims themselves, Oxford Economics says that while it now appears that we have passed the peak in layoffs, "jobless claims are poised to remain extraordinarily high in coming weeks as the economy plunges deeper into a recession."
  • NOTE: Next's week's initial jobless claims will coincide with the survey period for the BLS' Employment Situation Report.

subject: PRIMER: US initial jobless claims due at 0830 ET/1330 BST; 5.1mln expected in the week
content:
• EXPECTATIONS: The Street looks for initial jobless claims to print 5.105mln (the range, once again, is extremely wide at 1.4mln to 8mln) in the week ending 11th April, from last week’s 6.61mln. Continuing claims are seen at 13.5mln from last week’s 7.46mln. 
  • UNEMPLOYMENT: "Google searches for 'file for unemployment' are now falling consistently on a W/W basis, by about one third, if that trend continues, we’d expect headline claims next week to drop to about 4.5M," writes Pantheon Macroeconomics. The consultancy explains that this implies excess claims between the March and April payroll survey weeks will total some 20.1mln. "The hit to payrolls should be a bit less than that, because the gap between the surveys this time is five weeks rather than four, but even after allowing for this, we reckon May payrolls will be reported falling by about 19mln, driving the unemployment rate to 16% if none of the newly-unemployed leave the labor force." Pantheon says that seems unlikely, given that the labor force reportedly dropped by 1.6mln in March, when household employment fell by 3.0mln. "If that proportion repeats in April, headline unemployment will be about 10%, matching the peak after the Great Recession, but the true rate will be much higher, and it will rise further, along with the published rate, over the next few months."
  • CUMULATIVE: Morgan Stanley notes that the magnitude of the increase in weekly claims has likely moved passed its peak, but the cumulative number is still rising, and will likely be in the range of 25mln over the next few weeks (the cumulative number over the last three weeks of data is 16.7mln). The trend rate pre-COVID was about 220k per week. 
  • MARKET REACTION: In terms of the price reaction, SocGen said the two previous releases of weekly claims “did not knock investors out of their stride and spark a flattening bid in bonds,” so while the data may serve to remind traders of the magnitude of the situation, it will unlikely drive a significant downside price reaction similar to that seen after yesterday's retail sales/Empire Fed data. Additionally, Deutsche Bank reminds us that over the last three weeks, on days the initial jobless claims data has been released, the S&P 500 has actually rallied (6.2%, 2.3% and 3.4%).

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 16th April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment recovered from APAC lulls prior to European open; currently, remain modestly firmer ahead of US data deluge
  • President Trump added administration will be announcing new guidelines on reopening the economy on Thursday
  • ECB President Lagarde is fully prepared to increase the size of asset purchase programmes and adjust their composition, by as much as necessary and for as long as needed
  • DXY is firmer once again, but yet to breach the 100.00 mark to the upside with major peers subdued as such
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Initial Jobless Claims, Building Permits, Housing Starts, Philadelphia Fed Business Index, OPEC Monthly Oil Report, earnings from L'Oreal & LVMH

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US President Trump said our aggressive strategy is working and data suggests the nation has passed the peak on new coronavirus cases. Furthermore, President Trump added administration will be announcing new guidelines on reopening the economy on Thursday and urged the Senate to confirm his nominees to vacancies across the administration or formally adjourn and threatened to use executive powers to try and force both chambers of Congress to adjourn, while Senate Majority Leader McConnell later spoke with President Trump and pledged to find ways to confirm Trump nominees critical to fighting coronavirus although noted it will require consent from Democratic leader. (Newswires)

New Chinese export restrictions has left US Co's PPE due to be dent to the US stranded, according to diplomatic US memos cited by WSJ; with large quantities of PPE and medical goods sitting in Chinese warehouses across China. (WSJ)

UK Health Minister Hancock says it is too early to make a change to lockdown measures, virus would resurface if we ease measures right now, it does appear we are approaching a peak. Note, the UK is expected to announce an extension to its current lockdown period today until May 7th. Separately, under plans being considered by UK government advisers, the nation could be “segmented” into different risks groups which would allow young and healthy adults to return to work, with more vulnerable people set to remain shielded from the virus. (Times) UK Epidemiologist Ferguson states that significant social distancing will have to be maintained possibly until we have a vaccine for the virus. (Twitter)

Milan, Italy is reportedly asking the government to restart activities on May 4th. (Newswires)

German coronavirus cases rise to 130,450 (+2,866) deaths stand at 3,569 (+315), according to the Robert Koch Institute. (Newswires)

Japan's PM Abe is to declare a nationwide state of emergency, potentially through to May 6th, according to Yomiuri. Tokyo has around 149 new cases (prev. over 125) of COVID-19, according to NHK. Japan is reportedly to scrap plans of JPY 300k handouts to households, according to Kyodo.

ASIA

Asian equity markets remained subdued amid the headwinds from Wall St where risk sentiment was dampened by the ongoing oil market rout, weak earnings from the large banks and poor data releases, with comments from President Trump not helping to brighten the mood as he threatened to adjourn Congress if administration nominations are not confirmed. ASX 200 (-0.9%) was dragged by broad weakness across its sectors aside from some resilient patches among defensives and with corporate updates also providing a catalyst for individual stock moves, while Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) was dampened as coronavirus-related disruptions and shutdown extensions hampered Tokyo blue-chip manufacturers. Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) traded subdued as sentiment in Hong Kong was dampened amid the weakening economic climate with Hong Kong Financial Secretary Chan suggesting the government will likely downgrade its outlook, although losses in the mainland were limited as markets await tomorrow’s slew of tier 1 Chinese data including Q1 GDP which People’s Daily noted will remain positive despite the current expectations for a contraction of 6.5% Y/Y. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher amid the weakness seen across stocks and with prices underpinned following firmer demand at the enhanced liquidity auction in the long to super-long end.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0714 vs. Exp. 7.0596 (Prev. 7.0402)

PBoC says that it will maintain the normalisation of monetary policy for as long as possible and will keep room for monetary policy adjustments. The Bank will also continue to guide credit funds to support smaller firms through RRR targeted cuts, re-lending and other measures. (Newswires)

Chinese House Prices (Mar) Y/Y 5.3% (Prev. 5.8%). (Newswires)

Philippine Central Bank cut rates by 50bps to 2.75% in out of cycle move. (Newswires)

US

NY Federal Reserve will begin a regular publication of its Weekly Economic Index (WEI) from today to provide timely information on the state of the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Newswires)

US Small Business Administration urged Congress to appropriate additional funds for paycheck protection program, while it added it will not legally be able to issue new loan approvals once there is a lapse in appropriations for programs. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK BRC Retail Sales (Mar) Y/Y -3.5% (Prev. -0.4%). (Newswires)

Barclaycard said UK consumer spending fell 6% Y/Y in March which was the largest decline since the survey began in 2015, while it added that consumer confidence was also at the lowest on record for the survey. (Newswires)

ONS says 25% of companies surveyed reported they had temporarily ceased trading for the period of Mar 23-Apr 5; out of the businesses still trading, 21% of workforce has been furloughed. (ONS)

ECB President Lagarde says is fully prepared to increase the size of its asset purchase programmes and adjust their composition, by as much as necessary and for as long as needed. It will explore all options and all contingencies to support the economy. Assessing further requests for Euro swap lines. (Newswires)

ECB's Schnabel says that a rate cut would not have helped at a time (March 12th) when profits at banks were already under pressure. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

11 Iranian Revolutionary Guard boats made dangerous and harassing actions against 6 US naval ships in international waters in the North Arabian Gulf, while US crews took action deemed appropriate to avoid a collision. (Newswires)

Chinese Foreign Ministry says that the US' false accusations regarding nuclear testing are not worth refuting. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities hold onto most of their gains (Euro Stoxx 50 +1.0%) as prices were lifted around the entrance of European players following a less optimistic, more-so mixed, APAC lead. News-flow has been light thus far, although the price action seems to be more consolidation from yesterday’s moves. Late yesterday, France, Spain, Austria, Belgium, and Greece extended their short-selling ban on stocks to May 18th (originally set to expire in the coming days), albeit the respective bouses do not see significantly disproportionate price action vs. the region. Sectors are mostly in the green (ex-energy) but do not reflect a clear risk-tone. The IT sector outperforms as chip names see tailwinds from strong TSMC earnings, after the world’s largest contract chipmaker’s Q1 profit almost doubled on chip demand; albeit, H2 revenue is seen “flattish or may decline slightly”, the group also maintained its Capex guidance. Thus, the likes of STMicroelectronics (+3.0%), Infineon (+2.7%) and Dialog Semiconductor (+4.1%) remain underpinned. The sector breakdown sees Travel & Leisure towards the top of the pack amid tailwinds from easyJet’s (+3.0%) trading update in which it announced further steps to strengthen liquidity, which will be sufficient for a lengthy period of fleet grounding. Other individual movers include EDF (-5.9%) as shares feel the brunt of demand potentially falling to 20% of normal levels amid the virus outbreak.

BlackRock Inc (BLK) Q1 20 (USD): EPS USD 6.60 (exp. 6.16/6.20), Revenue 3.71 (exp. 3.6bln); AUM 6.47trln (exp. 6.59trln)

Bank of New York Mellon Corp (BK) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 1.05 (exp. 0.90), Revenue 4.11bln (exp. 3.85bln); 169mln credit provisions; AUM -2% at 1.8trln

TSCM (2330 TT) reported Q1 net income TWD 116.99bln vs. Exp. TWD 109.73bln, Operating profit TWD 128.5bn vs. Prev. TWD 64.3bln YY. Revenue TWD 310.6bln vs. Prev. TWD 218.7bln YY. Gross margin 51.8% vs. Exp. 45.3%.

Huawei is reportedly gradually shifting production of in-house designed chips away from TSMC to a Mainland-China supplier, in readiness for additional US restrictions, according to sources. (Newswires)

Apple (AAPL) - Co. is said to plan a boost to its wearables business with the launch of over-ear headphones. (Newswires)

FX

NZD/AUD - The Antipodean Dollars have both extended losses vs their US rival in wake of comments from RBNZ Governor Orr overnight reiterating that negative interest rates remain an option along with direct financing in response to the coronavirus, while a considerably better than expected Australian employment report was swiftly dismissed due to the early data reference period that preceded the closure of non-essential businesses due to COVID-19. The Kiwi is trying to hold above 0.5945 lows and Aussie reclaim 0.6300 vs 0.6266 or so at one stage as Aud/Nzd straddles 1.0550 ahead of key Chinese releases early on Friday, headlined by Q1 GDP, but also including March ip and retail sales.

JPY/EUR/GBP/CHF - All weaker against the Greenback as the DXY remains elevated within a 99.615-100.000 range, but with the Yen off worst levels and perhaps cushioned by decent option expiry interest at the 108.00 strike (1.8 bn) even though Japan is reportedly on the brink of extending its partial state of emergency from 7 prefectures to the whole country through to May 6. Similarly, the Euro could derive traction from multi-billion expiries under 1.0900 (1.0840-50 in 1.5bn, 1.0875 in 1.5bn, 1.0880-85 in 1.1bn) having derived very little if any support from not quite as bad as forecast Eurozone ip or ECB’s Schnabel ramming home the message that more conventional easing is counterproductive. However, the single currency did get some transitory momentum from Eur/Gbp cross flows as the pair bounced towards 0.8730 and Cable tripped some stops at 1.2460 awaiting official confirmation that UK lockdown will be prolonged until May 7 at least. Elsewhere, the Franc is still mixed just above 0.9700, but edging closer to 1.0500 vs the Euro following deeper Swiss producer and import price deflation (in y/y terms).

CAD/NOK/SEK - Relative G10 outperformers as some buoyancy in oil prices underpins the Loonie and Norwegian Crown after the former extended post-BoC losses, while the Swedish Krona has shrugged off softer Prospera money market inflation expectations and Riksbank-Riksdag wrangling over policy mandates amidst a modest upturn in broad risk sentiment.

EM - Although crude markets seem calmer to the benefit of the Rub, no such comfort for the Mxn in wake of Fitch downgrading Mexico to BBB from BBB-, as the Peso languishes under 24.4000 vs the Buck and not far from earlier April lows.

Australian Employment (Mar) 5.9k vs. Exp. -40.0k (Prev. 26.7k). Australian Unemployment Rate (Mar) 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.5% (Prev. 5.1%) Australian Full Time Employment (Mar) -0.4k (Prev. 6.7k)

RBNZ Governor Orr said have not ruled out negative interest rates, while he added that they are at the end of the beginning regarding monetary stimulus and suggested negative rates remain on the table as well as direct financing. (Newswires)

Fitch downgraded Mexico from BBB to BBB-; Outlook Stable and stated the economic shock from coronavirus will result to a severe recession in Mexico. (Newswires)

FIXED

Given the rebound in EU equities, Eurozone periphery paper adding to recovery gains and stability in oil, Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries are all displaying degrees of resilience pending the return of NA participants and the next weekly instalment of initial claims that will likely grab the bulk of attention and headline space amidst a raft of releases all at 13.30BST. The respective 10 year bonds are at 172.40 vs 172.04 at worst, 136.82 from 136.69 at the opening low and 139-04+ within 139-07+ to 138.30+ overnight session parameters. For the record, more solid demand for DMO issuance and strong French auctions vs more mixed, incomplete Spanish results, but UK debt and STIRs may glean some independent impetus from a speech on point by BoE’s Tenreyro at 14.30BST as she orates on policy during pandemics.

COMMODITIES

Choppy trade in the complex as WTI and Brent front-month futures nursed earlier losses and extend on gains throughout the European session thus far, with the former initially faring slightly better than the latter heading into the OPEC+ monthly oil market report, albeit this has now reversed and the difference between the contracts widens. WTI potentially saw some support from reports that the US will be paying drillers to leave the oil in the ground amid the supply glut. Traders will now be eyeing the report for the group’s 2020 outlook, especially after producers hammered out a deal over the weekend. For reference, IEA predicts 2020 global oil demand to slump 9.3mln BPD whilst EIA downgraded its forecast by 5.6mln BPD. IEA report also stated that no feasible agreement could cut supply by enough to offset near-term demand losses, so it will be interesting to see OPEC’s take on the market balance. WTI trades on either side of USD 20/bbl after printing an ~18yr base yesterday at USD 19.20/bbl. Brent prices meanwhile gain ground above 28/bbl with its respective YTD base around USD 21.70/bbl. Elsewhere, spot gold is back on a firmer footing and remains comfortably above USD 1700/oz. Some note that the rally in the yellow metal has been underpinned by significant inflows into ETFs. Spot gold sees its recent high at 1747.75/oz. Copper meanwhile, mirrors the gains in stocks, albeit price action in the red metal remains muted/contained. Finally, aluminium prices continued to rise with desks citing rising expectations of supply cuts driving the market alongside modest improvement in the Chinese markets.

Texas oil regulators are to meet April 21st to further discuss production limits. (Newswires)

Russia's St. Petersburg's oil terminal says the country has almost run out of spare storage space in Western regions. (Newswires)

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures pull-back in line with core counterparts
content: A somewhat deeper retracement in UK debt than envisaged at one stage pre-Liffe open, but underlying bids ensured no further losses or follow-through selling from the initial 136.69 print and the price action has been almost entirely restorative since with the 10 year debt future recently only 6 ticks adrift at 136.93. Similar story for Bunds as the early recovery rally in EU equities wanes, while 3 month contracts pare declines to stand narrowly mixed compared to 0.5-1 tick below par at worst. As such, less concession for looming DMO supply, if any is needed, following the BoE’s Q1 credit conditions survey and before a speech from MPC’s Tenreyro that appears much more pertinent given the subject matter (pandemic monetary policy).

Bunds: fading after another rebound
content: It’s a premature call, but after 2 constructive sessions for the 10 year German benchmark on return from the Easter holidays the trend may well end today given a more stable risk backdrop evident in firmer EU stock futures and Eurozone periphery bonds. Indeed, Bunds have attempted to follow the same pattern of recovery from overnight Eurex session lows, but only got as far as 172.50 vs Wednesday’s 172.68 close before losing momentum and retreating through 172.28 (the prior trough) to 172.12 and now consolidating off the new base into the cash bourse opens. Ahead, Eurozone ip and French supply, but a much busier US agenda with the spotlight on latest weekly claims after consecutive record-breaking tallies.

Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
16 April 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real-time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets remained subdued amid the headwinds from Wall St where risk sentiment was dampened by the ongoing oil market rout, weak earnings from the large banks and poor data releases, with comments from President Trump not helping to brighten the mood as he threatened to adjourn Congress if administration nominations are not confirmed. ASX 200 (-1.3%) was dragged by broad weakness across its sectors aside from some resilient patches among defensives and with corporate updates also providing a catalyst for individual stock moves, while Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) was dampened as coronavirus related disruptions and shutdown extensions hampered Tokyo blue-chip manufacturers. Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) traded subdued as sentiment in Hong Kong was dampened amid the weakening economic climate with Hong Kong Financial Secretary Chan suggesting the government will likely downgrade its outlook, although losses in the mainland were limited as markets await tomorrow’s slew of tier 1 Chinese data including Q1 GDP which People’s Daily noted will remain positive despite the current expectations for a contraction of 6.5% Y/Y.

EUROPE SHORT SELLING BANS

France, Spain, Austria, Belgium, and Greece have extended short-selling bans until May 18th, which were originally set to expire in the coming days. Authorities believe the restrictions are needed to stabilise stock prices following the March rout. (FT/Newswires) For reference, Italy’s ban is to continue until mid-June after the country imposed a 3-month short-selling ban on March 18th.

FTSE 100

Glencore (GLEN LN) – Co’s local subsidiary head in Zambia was temporarily detained by the Gov’t, due to the decision taken to close business for 3-months. (FT)

Banking Names - The BoE is testing commercial lenders to assess how severe a recession they could withstand. Deputy Governor Woods said that he is confident that high street banks were well-capitalised and would be able to lend into the real economy post-lockdown. (Times)’

Insurance Names – FCA has stated that, where the policy is valid, insurers must quickly assess and settle claims with small business relating to COVID-19; unwillingness to do so could result in counts against their regulatory record. (FT)

EX-DIVS: Croda (CRDA LN), M&G (MNG LN) and St James Place (SJT LN) will trade without entitlement to their dividend.

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES
